column3: A young blood prophet escapes from captivity on an alternate Earth where creatures called the Others domiate and humans are simply tolerated.
This mystery introduces Chief Inspector Armand Gamache of the Sûreté du Québec as he investigates a suspicious death in a rural tvillage outside of Montreal.
A mystery that explores the consequences of prejudice against independant women in the setting of a small English town.
Zoe must find her own path (and maybe love) after she is thrust suddenly from obscurity into the centre of political and magical power.

column1: Smarter Than You Think: How Technology is Changing Our Minds for the Better
column3: A very readable, tempered and engaging (if not comrehensive) argument about the impact of technology on the modern mind.

column1: The Girls of Atomic City: The Untold Story of the Women Who Helped Win World War II
column3: A narrative history exploring the lives of women who helped in the effort to refine uranium at Oak Ridge, Tennessee.
Sexy hilarity ensues when an awkward, bluestocking spinster runs away with a shameless, charming rake.
A frank yet compassionate account of how we die, encompasing the clinical and the philosophical and inspiring awe for both death and life.
Nonfiction account of the world's deadliest industrial disaster.

column1: The Information: A History, A Theory, A Flood
column3: This story paints a portrait of the key figures involved in the development of our modern understanding of information.
Satisfying revenge story for your bad days.

column2: Wu Ch'Eng-En, translated by Arthur Waley
column3: Classic Chinese literature about the Monkey King.
This book is highly recommended for the 80s and 90s gamers.
A teen girl finds she has a talent for helping others through the flowers she chooses for them.
Quippy fantasy set in an alternate universe Atlanta.
Princesses Vivenna and Siri attempt to navigate the world of political and mystical intrigue when one of them is sent to marry the God King of rival nation
Legion and his multiple personalities are drawn into a missing persons investigaton-- which quickly turns into a much deeper mystery.

column2: Neil Gaiman, illustrated by Yoshitaka Amano
column3: A humble young monk and a magical, shape-shifting fox are drawn together and into a devilish plot.
This story spans Japan's history and future, and connects traditional ghost stories with the worlds of organized crime and politics.
An ABC book for fans of the macabre.
Gretchen Rubin discovers the pleasure of writing just one sentence every day in this best-selling book.

column1: Chinese Watercolor Techniques for Exquisite Flowers
column3: Check out this book if you've always wanted to try Chinese style sumi-e.

column1: PostSecret: Extraordinary Confessions from Ordinary Lives
column3: Anonoymous participants submitted secrets via postcard in this art project-turned book.
This is an art book by one of today's leading contemporary artists.

column1: Obsessive Consumption: What Did You Buy Today?
column3: A sketchbook diary following Kate's daily spending.

column1: Show Me How: 500 Things You Should Know
column3: For picturebook fans, this is a simple how-to book to puzzle through.
Like vampires?  Like fantasy? Check out this book, which takes place in an alternate universe plagues by war and magic thieves.

column1: Freakonomics: A Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything
column2: Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner
column3: What do schoolteachers and sumo wrestlers have in common? Two economists use scenarios like this to connect economics and societal incentives.

column1: Cut and Fold Techniques for Promotional Materials
column3: A unique collection of over 40 attention-grabbing cut-and-fold designs.

column1: Sweet and Low: A Family Story
column3: The bittersweet book tells the story of a sugar substitute's invetor, and the toll  the project takes on his family.
A history of salt (and we mean the WHOLE history).
This novel explores fundamental questions of reality and identity.

column1: Caffeinated: How Our Daily Habit Helps, Hurts, and Hooks Us
column3: The history of the most popular drug in America.

column1: The Hot Zone: The Terrifying True Story of the Origins of the Ebola Virus
column3: A hair-raising account of the appearance of rare and lethal viruses and their "crashes" into the human race.

column1: Don't Sleep, There Are Snakes: Life and Language in the Amazonian Jungle
column3: Read a nonfictional account about the grammar and culture of the Piraha people in the Amazon.
This is the first book of the World of Watches series.This is recommended for folks looking for good versus evil.
Foundation, Foundation and Empire, Second Foundation.
Tina Fey reveals all in this hilarious memoir, and proves you're no one until someone calls you bossy.

column1: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
column3: The movie Bladerunner was based off of this book!

column1: The Collected Stories of Philip K. Dick
column3: Science fiction about false realities, human vs. machine, entropy, the nature of God, and social control
Unlike his other books (ie. Bourne series), this first book is a comedic thriller.
Set in the 1930s, a penniless royal solves mysteries that she encounters.

column1: The Secret History of the Pink Carnation
column3: With strong allusions to the Scarlet Pimpernel, the first book in this romance series involves subterfuge, historical research, and finding a dateable guy in London!
A gunslinger and his quests toward a tower in this tale, which incorporates fantasy, science fantasy, horror, and Western themes.
A king is poisoned, a magician schemes, and brothers duel for the throne in this intriguing fantasy adventure.
The last man on earth is hunted by all of the other once-human inhabitants, who have turned into vampire-like creatures.
NASA astronaut Mark Watney was accidentally left behind on Mars during an emergency evacuation. Can he survive until help arrives?
A comedian shares his favourite food memories.
An expansionist empire rules over the galaxy in this space opera, where humans are controlled by AIs.
